brief_summary.textblock:
Hemodialysis keeps patients with renal failure alive but does not restore normal health.
      Retention of chemicals that bind to plasma proteins and are therefore poorly removed by
      dialysis may contribute to ill health in patients receiving conventional treatment.  This
      proposal will test the effect of a new method designed to improve the removal of
      protein-bound solutes during dialysis.  The effects on blood chemical levels of two
      different dialysis prescriptions will be tested in patients already undergoing nocturnal
      in-center hemodialysis three times weekly.

clinical_study.brief_title: Increasing the Removal of Protein-Bound Solutes During Extended Hours Hemodialysis
clinical_study.condition: End Stage Renal Failure on Dialysis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  stable on nocturnal in-center dialysis located close to Stanford University and VA
             Palo Alto

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  recent use of antibiotics

          -  gastrointestinal disease

intervention.description: The subject will receive dialysis on the usual schedule and for the usual time but with a lower than usual dialysate flow and small dialyzer.
The subject will receive dialysis on the usual schedule and for the usual time but with a higher than usual dialysate flow and large dialyzer.

clinical_study.official_title: Increasing the Removal of Protein-Bound Solutes During Extended Hours Hemodialysis

primary_outcome.measure: Plasma levels of the chemical p-cresol sulfate
primary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for 2-3 weeks on different  dialysis prescriptions and plasma chemical levels will be measured at the end of this period.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.source: Palo Alto Institute for  Research and Education, Inc

lead_sponsor.agency: Palo Alto Institute for  Research and Education, Inc

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Basic Science
